1.content:
You find yourself in a room. You don't remember who you are or how you got there. Your mind is empty.

You are wearing a loose sleeveless shirt and a pair of loose shorts that are held up by a rope drawstring. Your clothes are the color of straw and feel like soft cotton.

On your feet are leather sandals with straps that crisscross around your ankles.

You call out "Is anybody here?" but no one answers.

The room is not large and the only furniture is a table. There are three doors leading out, each a different color.
1.title: In the beginning

11.content:
You open the blue door and gasp in surprise. It opens onto a ledge high on the side of a canyon. You are only a few steps from a sheer drop down to a river far below.

The ledge extends to the left and the right. You step out onto the ledge so that you can see better and the door slips out of your hand and slams shut! There is no handle, no doorknob, no way to get back inside.

The sun is low in the sky. Its rays shine down through the canyon. You can see a few birds circling in the air far below you. It feels like dawn, so you decide that East is the direction where the sun is rising. The sunlight sparkles on a small object by your feet. You pick it up.

It is a tiny silver figurine of a naked girl. A few strands of her hair are shaped like a loop and you can easily imagine this charm hanging on a necklace or bracelet. You put it in your pocket.

You know you can't stand here on the ledge forever so you make your move.
11.title: The Blue Door

choices: Go up out of the canyon.
111.content:
You walk east along the ledge, hugging the wall of rock to your left. You aren't all that afraid of heights, but the drop off to your right is a long, long fall down to the river at the bottom of the canyon.

You haven't gone far before you hear the faint sound of drums drifting up out of the canyon. As you round a bend in the trail, a village comes into view far below. It is only a few primitive huts by the riverside. There are some people at the edge of the river, some actually in the water. It's a long way off, but even at this distance you can see that they aren't wearing any clothes.

The trail forks here and one fork will carry you down to the village, while the other fork seems to go on up out of the canyon.
111.title: East on the Ledge

choices: Thank the villagers for the offer but decides to leave on your own.
1111.content:
You decide that your chances of survival are higher by heading to the village and figuring out what to do next. The music is lively enough that you get a comforted feeling that the villagers will be no harm.
You slowly shuffle your way off the ledge and walk slowly down towards the village, every step brings the volume of the drums higher and higher. You hesitate as you start to see glimpses of the simple little village and take a deep breath before cautiously walking through the opeing and presenting yourself to the villagers.
The vilagers draw close and look you over from head to toe, their expressions showing confusion and curiousity. They barely have any type of garments on, but they are decked out with numerous amounts of hand crafted jewelery. As you glance at some of the jewelery the naked figurine comes to mind and you quickly pull it out of your pocket.
The villagers step back from your quick movements but once the figurine is spotted they coo and shout with excitement and huddle around you with grins and pleased expressions. You stand there for a second and then try out your voice for the first time.
" What does this mean to you?" you ask as you hld out the figurine.
A random villager gives you a more than willing explanation.
"That figurine is a symbol of our village, resembling our innocence, freedom and happiness. The fact that you found this, shows that you are chosen to become part of this village and get very far in life as long as you stick with us. I am very excited that we might have a new member." The villager grins and as you look around you see many more ecstatic faces. You are sure they are waiting for a reply so you quickly think through your options and pick one.
1111.title: Head towards the village.

1112.content:
The trail climbs a little higher until you find yourself on a flat plain of rock. It looks barren and lifeless. Far off in the distance is a mountain, almost lost in the blue haze.

Nearer at hand is a group of boulders. You get the feeling that they have been arranged in a pattern. The word "stonehenge" flashes through your mind, but you are unable to relate it to anything and it quickly fades.
1112.title: Go up out of the canyon

11121.content:
The walking is not too difficult, but you are getting thirsty and the mountain seems to be getting no closer.

Suddenly there is a bolt of lightning off in the distance. It is in the direction of the boulders. As the thunder comes rolling across the plain, you are glad you didn't go over there. It looks like the lightning made a direct hit on the boulders.

You continue walking but the mountain gets no closer.

Finally, you stop and reconsider things. If you don't have something to drink, you will never make it to the mountain. Water is your top priority. You scan the area carefully, but all you see is a vast landscape of rock.

There are several birds circling overhead - large ones. The word "vulture" pops into your mind and back out again. You shudder, afraid of what they signify. You could die here. You could turn around and go back, but you have come a long way. It might be too far without water.

You hear the whistling call of a hawk overhead and look up. He is diving straight for you! At the last minute he pulls out of his dive and lands on a nearby rock where he cocks his head and looks at you.

He has something tied to his leg. He picks at it with his beak until it falls free and then with a few mighty flaps of his wings, he leaps back into the sky and flies away. You hear his whistling cry as he leaves.
11121.title: Mountain

111211.content:
You pick up what the hawk left behind - a small roll of paper. You unroll it and read__

Do not go to the mountain. You won't make it. You must go back to the room with three doors. Find the secret panel and jump up and down until it opens. That's all I can tell you. You might also have good luck with the green door, but whatever you do, avoid the red door.

_S.E.


You study the message. You don't know who S.E. is, but obviously he went to a lot of trouble to send you this message.

You look longingly at the mountain. The sun is setting, so low now that only the topmost peak of the mountain is illuminated. Then even that last light is gone and a deep blue sky full of stars is all you can see.

The air is getting colder and you have no sleeping bag, no tent, no matches, no knife. You feel very foolish and unprepared.

You decide you will rest for a few minutes, then immediately start back and find the room with the three doors.
111211.title: Message

11122.content:
When you get close to the boulders, you see that they are roughly cut in rectangular shapes and are arranged in four lines that form the sides of a square. That couldn't be natural, could it?

You walk into the center of the square and get a tingling feeling. The air seems charged with electricity here. There is a ringing in you ears. You cry out when you feel a sharp pain on your upper leg. It's that little figurine of a naked girl that you picked up and put in your pocket.

Suddenly a bolt of lightning flashes down out of the sky, splitting into four bolts that each strike one of the boulders at the corners of the square. BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM!

Now you are more than tingly, you are absolutely CHARGED UP with electricity. You strip off your shirt and shorts and sandals and run around naked screaming at the top of your lungs. You might be a little crazy now. In fact, you black out for a moment or two, but when you come back to your senses, you are still running around naked, only you aren't screaming anymore. You are just shouting something that sounds like "Hey! hey! Hey! Hey!" over and over.

You clamp your mouth shut and manage to stop your legs from running. It takes a big effort to stand still. You are trembling and shaking and suddenly you can't stand it anymore and start running and screaming again.

After a while, you manage to calm yourself down a little, but you still can't stop trembling, and every now and then a spasm of activity sweeps through you and you have to move your arms and legs, jump up and down and shout, do something, anything, just so you aren't standing still. It seems like hours before you can just stand quietly and think rationally.

Your first really rational thought is that maybe you should move away from these boulders. You find your clothes and sandals where you threw them on the ground. You walk a little distance from the boulders and put your clothes back on.
11122.title: The Boulders

111221.content:
You stand at a safe distance from the square of boulders and try to understand what just happened.

Apparently you triggered some kind of electrical discharge when you entered the square and the electricity affected your brainwaves. Suddenly you remember the sharp pain you experienced on your leg, right under the little figurine in your pocket. You pull out the silver figurine and examine it.

It is only a few centimeters long and not very detailed. It is a naked girl with long flowing hair. Some of the hair sweeps up and over to form a loop. It looks like a charm for a bracelet or necklace. Could this have something to do with the lightning bolt? You decide to try a little experiment.

You approach close enough to the square of boulders so that you can throw accurately. You toss the little figurine into the square and run back to a safe distance. Within seconds a bolt of lightning streaks down from the sky and splits into four bolts that strike the corners of the square. "Aha!" you think. "So it was the little charm that did it."

"Why did you call me?" says a voice behind you and you whirl around. Standing there is a woman who resembles the figurine except that she is very tall, taller than you. But she is silver. Everything - her skin, her hair, even her eyes - are silver. Yet she moves and talks like a living woman. Again she says, "Why did you call me?"
111221.title: The Naked Girl

choices: To Speak or Not to Speak
1112211.content:
You are speechless. Finally you manage to say, "I... I didn't call you."

The silver woman cocks one eyebrow. She doesn't believe you. She walks over to the square of boulders and picks up the little silver charm that you threw. She holds it up before your eyes. "Is this yours?" she asks.

"I threw it in there, but I didn't know what it would do. I didn't know that it would 'call' you."

She looks at you for a long moment. "You are one of the new ones." It's a flat statement. You don't know how to respond. You don't know what she means.

She continues. "You don't know who you are, do you? Maybe I can help you. Sometimes I am called the Silver Lady. You may address me as 'Lady'. I am not a being of your plane of reality. What you see is my avatar. It's essence is a pattern of energy, but I have chosen the element silver to give my avatar a form that you can see. My true nature is different from yours. However, like you, I am a conscious being with thoughts and memories. Do you understand what I am saying?"

"I think so. You are a conscious being from another dimension. You choose to appear to me as a silver woman, although that is not your true shape."

"Yes. Very good. Now who are you? That's the question you really want answered, isn't it?"

"Yes," you say. "I want to know."

The Silver Lady pauses. "It's not an easy question to answer, because, although you play an important role in something of great significance, your lack of knowledge of certain things is essential if you are to be successful. Are my words still clear?"

"I think so. I'm part of something big, but if I know too much about it, I want be able to do what I am supposed to do."

"Excellent! You have a sharp mind and can slice into the heart of the matter. I am old, very old. I cannot be as simple as you. Too much has happened. I will tell you this. You are not the only one, but you will never meet any of the others. The way will always be clear. Do not make any foolish decisions. And now I must go."

"Wait!" you say. "I have more questions!" But it is too late. The Silver Lady disappears in a clap of thunder. The little breeze generated by her abrupt departure stirs up some dust which quickly settles. Then all is quiet.

You look around and realize you don't have any idea what to do next. You think back over your conversation with the Silver Lady and sigh. She has told you nothing.
1112211.title: The Naked Woman

11122111.content:
"So," you murmur to yourself, "I'm going to be some big historical figure, but be totally ignorant of what I'm doing?" you let your shoulders slump slightly and sigh, "Won't be hard considering Ms. Murcury didn't tell me anything."

         You turn to look at the village again. More people have gathered out in the water and many of them are looking at the hilltop. "Don't know where I am, don't know what to do, might as well mingle with the locals." Tossing the silver woman pendant into the air and snatching it out of the sky, you head down towards the village.
11122111.title: To speak, or not to speak...

choices: Return it to the door you emerged from for the next guy
11122112.content: "If I'm part of something big, and this is the key to calling for help... I should do something with it," you tell yourself. You feel the warmed siver amulet with your fingers and decide to...
11122112.title: Something Else

111221121.content:
"Incase I'm not the last," you say walking back down the deserted path. You also note that the lightning storm has riled the villagers and now the drums are beating like crazy.

"Hmmm, I guess they didn't like the light show," You return to the door that stranded you here. But, you have a purpose, but ol' mirror face can't tell you anything about it. WHY does life have to be hard? You seem to recall feeling that way a lot. But you are positive this is the first time a transdimentional amazon streaker has put you in this particular predicament.

You can head back up to the plateau, or see what the locals know about strangers appearing with amnesia.
111221121.title: Return it to the door you emerged from for the ...

choices: Find a safe place to sleep in the rocks.
112.content:
You head west on the ledge, hugging the wall of rock to your right. It's not that being up so high above the canyon floor scares you, but there are no guard rails to protect you from falling off the left of the trail. One slip could be fatal.

There is the sound of pebbles falling next to you and you flinch, fearing a rockslide, but it's only a small animal scrambling away. You don't recognize the species of the critter, but then you don't recognize anything else either.

You haven't gone very far when you look over the edge and see a boat tied up on the riverbank far below. Someone is getting into the boat. They are dressed like you in straw-colored shorts and shirt. "Hey!" you yell. "Hey! Up here!" But the wind whips your words away and the little figure down below does not look up. There is no way to climb down to the boat. You decide to keep walking.

You walk for several hours before you find a small spring bubbling out of the rocks. You satisfy your thirst. Now, if you only had something to eat.

As if in answer to your wishes, you discover a tree covered with yellow fruit. It's nothing you are familiar with, but when you bite into one, it tastes juicy and sweet. You fill your pockets and keep walking.

Eventually, the sun completes it's trip across the sky and you know it will be getting dark soon. You are tired, but not exhausted.
112.title: West on the ledge

1121.content:
You know you don't want to be walking along a high ledge at night, so you look around for a safe place to spend the night. You come to a place where some rock has broken loose from the cliff wall. You settle down behind the loose rock and try to get comfortable.

It's a miserable way to sleep and you wake up over and over again during the night. Finally the first light of the new day appears and you stand up and stretch. You eat some of the yellow fruit.

Your mind is still a blank. You don't know who you are or where you are. You sigh and continue walking along the ledge path.

You walk all day and then late in the afternoon you realize that you are not as high above the river. The canyon is opening out into a flatlands. By the time the sun sets, you are walking beside the river. The path is well-trodden, but you have yet to meet another person.

You are tired after walking all day. You bathe in the river, eat some yellow fruit, and make a bed for yourself in the tall grass. You fall asleep as soon as you lie down.
1121.title: The Second Day

11211.content:
You wake up early next morning, but not as early as the sun. It is already first light. You yawn and stretch. That was a good night's sleep and you feel well-rested.

Your ears perk up. You hear voices not far away. A woman calls out. You hear children laughing and playing. You crawl through the weeds until you are close to the sounds. You peek through the tall weeds.

There is a small group of people on the edge of the river. You see three small children and two older girls, and a woman old enough to be their mother. The woman has a bright yellow cloth wrapped around her, but the girls and children are all naked. The girls are washing themselves in the river. The small children are playing.

The two girls are very beautiful as the rays of the morning sun shine on them. Their wet skin glistens. Their figures are slender and graceful, just beginning to fill out. You catch your breath as one of them raises her arms up to run her hands through her hair. She seems to be looking right at you.

But then she pushes her sister down in the water and the younger girl comes up sputtering and angry. The older sister runs off, just out of the younger one's reach. They twist and turn, zig and zag, as they chase each other. Suddenly, they are headed right for your hiding place!
11211.title: The Third Day

112111.content:
There is nowhere else for you to go. They are bound to discover you. You decide to stand up and reveal yourself.

The two girls scream when they see you. "Mother!" the older one calls, and they both race back to the river.

Their mother turns her head, and sees you standing in the weeds. There is fear in her eyes, but she stands firmly. The girls hide behind her.

"Come here", she commands you.

You obey, and are soon standing in front of her.

"Who are you?" she asks softly.

"I do not know", you reply.

Her eyes narrow. "Nonsense. Tell me who you are at once."

"I am telling you the truth. I don't know who I am or where I am. I woke up in a strange room. I opened a blue door. I have been travelling down the mountain for three days. I have eaten the yellow fruit and slept in among the rocks. That is all I can tell you."

The woman's eyes grow wide. "You have eaten the yellow fruit?"

"Yes," you reply. What now?

"Come with me. Quickly", she says. "When did you eat it?"

"Yesterday and today", you tell her.

"There might still be time", she mumbles. "Come girls, we are going back to the village. Run!"

You run for roughly two miles through the wilderness. The women and children are very fit, but you are soon winded. The strange woman grows very impatient with you. "Would you hurry?" she snaps.

Eventually, you arrive at a village. "Go home", the woman in yellow says to her children. "I will be home later. Tell your father we are gone to visit Sirus."

The older girl looks concerned. "Sirus? Father has forbidden you from seeing him, Mother".

"I do not care what Father has forbidden", the woman snaps. "This girl needs his help. Now go home."

The girl gives her mother a look, and follows the rest of the girls home.
112111.title: Yellow Fruit

1121111.content:
You follow the woman through the village. Although the huts are made of mud, they are all whitewashed with lime and gleam brilliantly in the sunshine. You enter a hut through a narrow opening in its cylindrical wall.

Inside the hut it is dark until your eyes adjust. A very old man, small and wrinkled, sits crosslegged on a mat. Asleep?

"Sirus?" the woman says. "Sirus?"

The old man looks up with watery eyes that seem to sag at the lids so that the bottom lids show some red. "What is it?" he asks in a husky, rattling voice like wind blowing through dried cornstalks.

"This girl has eaten of the yellow fruit during the time of full moon."

Sirus turns to look at you. "Child, you know that the moonfruit must not be eaten when Luna smiles. Who are your parents?"

When you remain silent, the woman speaks up for you. "She is not from here. She says she does not know her name or where she is from."

Sirus studies you. "You know nothing at all?"

You finally find words to speak. "No, just that I am here on the river and talking to you." You feel tears forming in your eyes. Everything is too strange. It's too much to understand.

Sirus sees your discomfort. "Be at ease child, You are safe here. Martha will take care of you. She has two daughters of her own. They will welcome you. But first we must do something about the moonfruit. It is not good for a girl to eat moonfruit when the moon is full."

"Why not?" you ask, wiping the tears from your eyes.

"Because that is part of the Old Way that we have abandoned. There was much evil in those days. Young girls like yourself were transformed into depraved monsters that terrorized entire villages. The girls had to be hunted down and killed and sometimes innocent girls were killed by mistake. It was an awful time to be alive."

"But what about me?" you whisper. "I ate the moonfruit when the moon was full."
1121111.title: Sirus

11211111.content:
Martha touches your shoulder. "Do not be afraid. Sirus will help you."

"Wait!" you say, as Martha turns to leave. "Please stay. Please don't leave me alone with him."

"It's all right," Martha says. "He will not hurt you. I will see you when he is through."

You watch her leave. Now you are alone with Sirus. "Take off your clothes," he says.

You look down at the floor. In a small voice you say "Why? I don't want to..."

"Look at me," he commands, and you do. "It is necessary. Do it." His eyes are hypnotic.

You slowly remove the shirt and shorts that are your only garments.

"Stand still and face me," Sirus says.

You stand naked before him as he looks you over. When you see where his eyes linger, you cover yourself there with your hand.

"Don't cover yourself. Keep your hands by your side and look straight ahead."

You take a deep breath and follow his instructions. You are trembling a little. You can almost feel his gaze looking into you. You try to relax.

"That's it," Sirus says. "Just be calm. Relax. Let the tension flow out of you. Breathe slowly. That's it. Relax..." He continues on and on like that in his dry, husky voice...



You are startled, and realize that you have been asleep for a moment or two. Martha is in the room.

"You can get dressed now," she says.

"What happened? How long was I asleep?"

"Not long," Martha says, smiling. But when you step outside the hut of Sirus, you see that the sun has moved down near the horizon.

"What did he do to me?" you ask Martha.

"He made you well. He took away the badness of the moonfruit and replaced it with goodness."

"But how? Why was I asleep?"

Martha laughs and shakes her head. "You have many questions. I do not know the answers."

"I don't like Sirus," you say.

Martha smiles. "No one does."
11211111.title: Treatment

choices: Go to the nearest pub and buy some food for later
Run, run as fast as the wind can take you!
112111111.content:
"Ugh, I feel dirty," you shudder.

Martha takes a hold of your shoulder and squeezes it lovingly. "If you say what is true that you know nothing of yourself, I more than welcome you to our family." She smiles warmly.

"Tha-thank you," you say.

You and Martha walk to her house. It's nothing more than a one story brown hut. You walk inside, and you have to duck to get in. You notice that you are a head taller than everyone you have met. You see a big burly man sitting in the middle of the room at a long dark wood table. That must be Martha's husband.

"Hello," you say, awkwardly, not looking at the man's eyes.

"Who is this?" he asks Martha.

"This is... ummm... Luna." She made up the name. You give her a quick look of uncertainty. Luna?

The man scratches his beard. "Luna? Hmmm...."

You shrug. "I guess... yes."

"Where are you from, Luna?"

"I don't know," you say.

"She doesn't know?" He narrows his eyes at you and then looks suspiciously at his wife. Martha cringes.

The man gets loud. "Did she come from the mountains? The forbidden mountains?"

"We don't know, Fidek. We found her by the bathing circle." She looks at you and gives you a look as to go along with what she is saying.

The man stands up, he is couple of inches taller than Martha, but still shorter than you. You try not to laugh at his ridiculous features. He is stocky, yet so short.

Fidek's voice booms, "Get out of my house you demon worshiper!"

"But, I'm not-", you try to speak.

"GET OUT!" he screams. He looks at Martha. "Did you take her to Syrus?"

"N-no!" She shakes where she stands.

"Lying woman! Take this demon worshiper out of my house before she taints it!"

Martha, left without a choice, takes you outside. You see tears in her eyes. "I'm so sorry!" she says sadly.

"That's alright." You try to sound confident. "Are you going to be ok?"

"Yes. Remember the girls that I told you about that ate the forbidden fruit? Well, one of the girls that were killed to purify our land from the demon girls was his sister. And he takes that really close to heart. Fidek thinks that Syrus is a hoax who tries to take money from people." She fumbles in her apron.

"Why did you help me then?" you ask.

"Because my sister was killed. She was an innocent one that Syrus actually cured. But nobody listened. They didn't want to take chances." She takes out a little pouch and hands it to you.

"What is this?" you ask, looking at the palm of your hand. The bag feels heavy.

"It's some money to help you get by for a little while. I was thinking that Fedik might do this, so I acted in advance," she smiled.

"I can't take this from you. I hardly even know you!"

"No please, you remind me so much of my younger sister. I want to help you the way I never got to help her." Martha starts to cry.

"Thank you, Martha!" you smile.

At that moment Fedik comes out with an angry face. "Leave before I get you killed girl!" he says through clenched teeth, and takes Martha inside.

You walk away from the house a little frightened and feeling more alone than before.
112111111.title: Leaving the town

1121111112.content:
As hungry as you feel you decide to leave the town before anyone else starts questioning where you are from. You walk for about an hour or so, not really sure about what time and day it is. You have been walking in a clearing for a while now, with nothing around but grass and a few little trees scattered around here and there. You start walking up a huge hill, when you realize that you have stepped upon a great precipice.

"Wow" you say to yourself. All you see is a really dark and lush forested area about a mile wide and a mile long. You can't really see anything inside because there are huge trees guarding it.
1121111112.title: Enchanted Forest

1122.content:
You keep walking as the sun sets. It's very spooky as it gets darker and darker.

What's that? You jump back when you hear a noise. Uh-oh!

Forgot you were on a ledge, didn't you? You tumble off the ledge and take the long fall to oblivion.

You look down at your self. Not any different! You are still the same!

You see a tree house in front of you and a dirt path beside you...

114.content:
Looking around rather desperately, you dig through your mind for anything you might remember. But can you really remember anything? Can you remember being born? Were you ever born...wait, what's "born" again?

Frustrated, you kneel over the very edge of ledge and strain your eyes so that you might see the bottom. No- you're just too high up. Suddenly you feel the figurine slipping from your pocket. Gasping and throwing your hands over the girl, you save her as though she were your only friend. And who knew? Maybe she was...and maybe she could help.

You inspect her closely, stroking her silver head. Maybe, just maybe, you could ask for help...

But wait- how would you ask? You could write...but you don't know how to write...explaining in words is no good, yo don't speak any language you can recall. So you clutch the silver girl close to your chest and wish with all your might to appear...somewhere else.

12.content:
You open the green door. Outside is a lush growth of plants. You don't recognize any of them, but you are not sure if that means anything since your mind feels so empty.

The air smells fresh and you can hear water running. You take a few steps forward and hear the door slam shut. There is no doorknob or handle. You will not be going back inside.

You walk toward the sound of the water and come to a river. You realize that you are in a tremendous canyon. Walls of rock reach far into the sky on either side of the river.

There is a small boat tied up at the edge of the river. Could someone be here? You shout again, but no one calls back.

There is a path leading from the boat and continuing along the riverbank towards the rising sun which is sending it's rays down through the canyon. That must be east, you decide. The river flows away to the west.

You could get in the boat and float downstream or you could walk up the path and see where it takes you.
12.title: The Green  Door

121.content:
You walk east on the path that runs beside the river. You haven't gone very far before you hear the faint sound of drums.

As you round a bend in the trail, you see a village of primitive huts. They are made of woven grasses and look like big upside down baskets. From one of them comes the sound of drums. In the river, not far upstream from the huts, there are some women and children. It's not clear what they are doing, but you can see that they are naked.

You study the village. Everything looks peaceful. There does not seem to be any reason why you shouldn't enter it.
121.title: Walk east along the path

1211.content:
You walk closer to the village. The huts are made of cleverly woven plants. Like big baskets, you think.

The noise of the drums is coming from the largest hut. You push aside the woven curtain that covers the entrance. The drumming comes to a sudden stop.

Inside the hut a dozen pair of eyes fixate on you. "Uhhh... Hi!" you say, giving them your best smile.

You are glad they are humans. But they don't smile back. They turn to look at an old man with a bald head and he speaks to you, but his words are gibberish to you.

You decide to give them the "Me Tarzan, you Jane" routine but, when you pound your chest, you remember that you don't remember your name. You shrug your shoulders and smile sheepishly. For some reason the shoulder shrug sets the natives to talking amongst themselves.

The old man speaks again. He seems to be talking louder and slower. Finally he shrugs his shoulders. You don't understand what he means, but you match his gesture with a shrug of your own. Again the natives engage in animated chatter with each other.

You pick up one of their drums and inspect it. You tap a little beat on it with your hand and the room suddenly grows quiet. Uncertain what to do, you decide to try to imitate the rhythm you heard them playing when you entered the village.
1211.title: The Village

12111.content:
You start pounding out a fairly good imitation of the rhythm they were playing. Maybe that work as a drummer in school will finally pay off. it sure didn't pay off back when you thought your band was going to make it big.

One of the natives joins in and then another and soon everybody is pounding away on the drums. This goes on until you begin to wonder if it is all they do, but the old man raises his hands and everybody stops drumming.

There is a commotion outside and you see more villagers entering the village. Maybe they were down by the river washing clothes or catching fish. Some of the boys have strings of fish.

You realize the clothes washing angle is not too likely. There are not many clothes being worn. But obviously they were off somewhere doing something.

Seeing the fish makes you realize how hungry you are. You get the old man's attention and pretend you are eating something. He doesn't understand, but one of the women does and chatters something at one of the girls. Soon a basket of yellow fruit is placed before you. You try one. They taste good.
12111.title: The Drums

121111.content:
There is a commotion at the door and one of the boys brings in a small wicker chest. The old man is delighted. He opens the chest and takes out somrthing that looks like a dried fig on a leather thong. You are horrified when you realize that it is a dried human ear.

"We can speak now," says the old man. You look up quickly. You heard the old man's voice doubled, with gibberish coming from his mouth and words in your own language coming from the dried ear.

"What is this thing?" you ask.

The old man smiles and nods his head, "This is the ear of my father, Thol Bryn. He was a very powerful man, a teacher and a healer. Now we can talk. What is your name?"

Should you tell him you don't know who you are? "I'm not sure," you say. But that sounds stupid. So you add, "I don't know my name. I woke up this morning in a room with three doors and I don't remember anything before that."

The old man nods. "You are a visitor. You are welcome to stay here. I will call you Traveler."

"All right," you agree. "Traveler... What is your name?"

"I am Tal Bryn, the first son of Thol Bryn," he says. "I am the father of these people."

You wonder if he means they are all his children, but you decide it just means he is the head man in the village.
121111.title: Translator

1211111.content:
"Are you hungry?" Tal Bryn asks.

"Yes, I am."

"We will eat soon." Then he says something to one of the women, but the ear does not translate it. Perhaps you have to talk directly at the translator ear to make it work.

One of the girls has been looking at you and she comes over to stand near you. She says "I am Trilla." Her eyes are a deep brown and her skin is a light brown. Her hair is a shade in between and is very long and straight and shiny. She only wears a strip of cloth around her waist.

You don't know what to say to her so you just say "Hello, Trilla" and it seems to be enough. She smiles. She touches your arm and it seems magical. It isn't just that her hand is warm. Something seems to pass from her to you. Without knowing why, you feel that somehow she has claimed you, that you are her possession now. It's not an unpleasant feeling.

She gently takes your arm and points at the river. "Do you want to bathe?" she asks.

"Yes, that would be nice," you say. You can see a fire being built and preparations for a meal being made. Boys are cleaning fish and girls are cutting up vegetables.

One of the boys and a girl come with you and Trilla as you walk down to the river. The girl has a waist wrap like Trilla, but the boy wears a loincloth made of woven leaves. At the river's edge, they are not shy about dropping their clothes on the ground and wading in. You only hesitate a moment before joining them.

You had to leave the translator ear with Tal Bryn, but even though you can't understand what anyone is saying without the translator, you can catch the sense of it, and when the boy splashes water in your face and laughs, you know it's time for a water fight.

The four of you laugh and play in the water until you hear a call from the village.
1211111.title: Trilla

12111111.content:
There are no tables or chairs. Everyone sits crosslegged on grass mats. Bowls carved from wood are heaped with steaming piles of food. Everyone has a big wooden spoon, but the bowls are shared.

There is some light chatter as everyone digs into the food, then only the sounds of eating. You are hungry and everything tastes good.

After a while, the conversation starts up again. Trilla sits beside you and, as your belly gets full, you shift your attention from the food to her. Her slim tan body looks strong. There is nothing skinny or weak about her. She feels your gaze on her and turns to you with her deep brown eyes.

She smiles and you get lost in her eyes, so deep and brown and sparkling with little lights that seem so mysterious and inviting. They call to you and you sigh. Then you laugh as you realize that you have stopped eating and are just staring into her eyes. She laughs too, and you hear other laughter. You look around and the girl that swam with you asks "You like Trilla?"

"Yes," you say. "I like Trilla very much." And there is more laughter.

The sun was setting when the feast began. By the time everyone has eaten their fill, the night has fallen.

The boys build up the fire until it is a roaring bonfire. The drums are brought out and a rhythm begins. It is slow and sensuous. The girls begin singing a song and it is a song that stirs your heart. You don't know the words. The ear cannot translate so many voices at once. But you feel the mood of it, the feeling of loneliness and beauty.

Then the rhythm of the drums changes, a slightly faster, more emphatic beat, and the girls get up and begin to dance.

They are all beautiful, but your eyes always return to Trilla. Her body moves in waves of fluid motion that make your heart sing. You realize that the night has only just begun. A wave of pleasure sweeps through your body and you tremble. You have to dance. You get up and go to Trilla. Some of the other boys are already dancing with the girls. You lock eyes with Trilla and begin to move.
12111111.title: Feast

121111111.content:
The next morning, you walk off by yourself to a place where a large boulder stands by the river. You climb up on the boulder and look out at the river. The sun is just beginning to rise and the first long golden rays of a new day sparkle on the water.

The night with Trilla was wonderful. You must make a decision. Stay here or go on? You don't know where you came from, who you are, or where you should go. But you know you like this place. You like the river and the village and the people. But most of all you like Trilla.

"I love her," you whisper to yourself and you know that you have made your decision.
121111111.title: Forever?

122.content:
The boat seems seaworthy. The current in the river is not very fast.

The word "kayak" pops into your head and you remember other rivers and other journeys, but the memories quickly fade leaving nothing but the mysterious word "kayak" in your mind. You decide to name this boat Kayak. Something deep inside you says that you must name your boat to insure a safe journey. You have no idea why you believe that.

You get into Kayak and untie her. The current pulls you downstream.

You are thirsty and drink some of the river water. It tastes clean and fresh. If you only had something to eat. Occasionally you see a fish swimming in the clear river, but how to catch it?

You pull Kayak up onto a sandbar and stretch your legs. You have no idea where the river will carry you, but you feel good, except for the hunger. The sun shines bright and the canyon is cool and interesting to look at.

You notice black objects like pebbles along the edge of the sandbar in the shallow water, but when you pick one up to examine it, you see that it is a small animal with a shell. You smash the shell against a rock and taste the contents. Not bad. You eat a number of the little shellfish until you are no longer hungry.

You judge it will be dark soon. Maybe you should spend the night here on this sandbar where food is abundant.
122.title: Kayak

1221.content:
You pull Kayak up on the sandbar and turn her on her side to make a windbreak for the depression in the dry sand that will be your bed. You lie on your back and gaze at the stars. A meteor streaks across the night sky.

A noise off in the trees disturbs your reverie. It sounds like a grunt and a snuffle. An animal? You sit up quickly wishing you had looked for a big stick before you lay down. Quietly you feel around the ground for a makeshift weapon. Your hand closes on a large rock.

The snuffles and grunts draw closer until you feel the creature is only a short distance away.

You throw the rock as hard as you can and are rewarded with a loud "Yelp!" from the creature. Bulls-eye! You hear it shuffle off through the underbrush.

But now you are worried. Will it come back? Are there more of them? You don't want to lay down and sleep. You are afraid you will be attacked in your sleep.

You sit down in the sand with your back to the water. In front of you the brush is thick and very dark. The canyon wall is behind the brush, just an inky blacknes, but when you look up, you can see it's silhouette against the stars.

You wonder what's happening, who you are and why you are here. If you could only remember. But when you try to think about the past you meet a black wall, just like the walls of this canyon. You remember waking up in the room with three doors, but nothing from your life before.

There is no repeat of the animal incident and finally you fall asleep.
1221.title: Sandbar

12211.content:
Your sleep is fitful. You wake up from dreams of animals chasing you, from dreams of falling from high places, from dreams of drowning. Each time you manage to get back to sleep.

Once the snap of a twig wakes you up and you spend long moments gazing into the underbrush, another large rock in your hand.

But you are so tired. You always fall asleep again. And dream...
12211.title: Restless Night

122111.content:
Three girls are dancing on a lily pad. Are these girls very tiny, or is it a very large lily pad? They wear ballerina costumes. One is blue. One is green. One is red.

There is music playing, thin tinkly music like a music box. The girls move gracefully in time with the music.

Suddenly there is a snort and a grunt and the girls scream. They throw up their arms and dance away to the right. From the left comes a gigantic bear reared up on his hind legs, shuffling his feet in time with the music. He is dancing, but the dance is not graceful.

A shot rings out and the bear falls to all fours, growling and snarling. The music box speeds up to double speed. The three ballerinas come spinning and twirling back on the scene. The bear swipes at them with his huge paw again and again, but always misses.

Until he manages to swat the red ballerina and she crumples to the ground. The blue and green ballerinas scream and beat the bear's face with their small fists. The bear swats them both and all three girls are down on the ground, unmoving. The bear's huge muzzle sniffs at the red ballerina. He opens wide his huge jaws and_

You wake up sweating. Is that a sound in the brush? You are nervous and trembling. You do not fall back asleep, but sit there wide awake until dawn.
122111.title: Dream

1221111.content:
You are so glad to see the sun come up. There is a mist on the river this early in the morning, but you are anxious to move on. You pick up more of the little black shellfish and toss them into the bottom of Kayak. Then you push off into the current and float downstream.

By midmorning you are out of the canyon. The river is wider and there are lots of tall weeds along the banks. You see a boat just like yours pulled up in the weeds. Up on the bank above are three people around a fire - a man, a boy, and a girl. They are all wearing the same straw-colored clothes as you wearing. You wish you had a paddle so that you could talk to them, but the current carries you on past them. You don't think even notice you float by. They seem to be totally involved in their breakfast.

By midday you are floating through a region of farmlands. You can see fields of crops and an occasional building off in the distance. You float past a fisherman on the riverbank and he waves back at you.

The river is wide and sluggish now. Up ahead you see a stone bridge that spans the river. A wagon is crossing over the bridge just as you are floating under it. You wave at the wagon driver, then abruptly stop waving. He isn't human.

You catch a glimpse of reptilian skin with a black and white pattern of swirls and dots. His head is odd, with a short snout, and eyes well to the sides. Then you lose sight of him as Kayak drifts under the bridge. By the time you come out the other side, the wagon is well down the road, a cloud of dust behind it. You shudder. This place is stranger than you thought.

Later in the afternoon, you come to a second bridge. This may be a good place to pull ashore. You are hungry and you can see no reason to stay on the river.

Now that you know these lizard creatures are around, you are worried that they may not be friendly. You are exposed on the river. It might be better to take to the road where there are places to hide. Maybe the lizard creatures are friendly. But maybe they are not. You need to know.
1221111.title: The Second Day

12211111.content:
You pull ashore under the bridge, carefully hiding your boat in the weeds in case you need it again.

There are the remains of old fires under the bridge. You are not the first to camp here. It's only a few hours until sunset, so you spend the time gathering dry grass for a bed. There are no buildings near the bridge. Occasionally a wagon crosses the bridge, but they are unaware of you hiding below. You rest on your bed of grass until it is dark, then you set out to explore.

You look up and down the dark roadway. In one direction you see a light, so you head that way. As you draw closer to the light, you see that it comes from the window of a small house. The house has a low stone fence and flowers in the yard, although it's too dark to judge their true colors. The place seems harmless enough - if it's inhabited by humans.

You enter the yard quietly and go to the window where the light is shining. You peek inside and see a woman sitting in a rocking chair reading. There is a lamp on the table beside her. Safe enough, you think. You go around to the door and knock.

"Who is it?" she calls from inside without opening the door.

"I am lost," you say. "Can you help me?"

"What do you mean 'lost'? Go away!"

"Please! I need help. I don't know who I am or what's happened to me!"

She must hear the desperation in your voice because she cracks the door and looks at you. "Where do you come from?"

"I don't know. I don't know anything. I found a boat on the river. Please help me."

She opens the door. "Come in then. Let's hear your story."

But what can you tell her except the room with three doors, the canyon, the river, the boat, the sandbar, the bridges.

She scratches her chin. That's Nevermore Canyon," she says. "I've got a second cousin that lives up in there at the village of Tal Bryn. But you say you didn't see any village in the canyon?"

"No."

"Then your room with three doors must be on this side of his village. If you found a boat on the riverbank, then you must have been very near to Tal Bryn's village. I don't know why you should be there? Are you part of the Sisyski Delegation?"

"Sisyski? I don't know what you are talking about."

"You've never heard of the League of True Planets? You don't know that this is Nevermore?"

"I don't know ANYTHING!"

The woman seems to believe you. "Very puzzling... I don't know who you are or what you are, and obviously you don't know. Would you like me to call a policeman?"

A chill runs through you. Why should that frighten you? "A policeman?" you say. "No, I don't think that's needed. I'll be okay."

The woman looks skeptical. "But you need some help. Perhaps a doctor can help you get your memory back?"

"No... No... I'm fine. Well, I guess I better be going. You've been a big help. Thanks a lot." And you head for the exit.

"Wait!" says the woman and grabs your arm. "I really don't think you should be out there by yourself, not knowing who you are and all. Just sit down and don't be afraid."

You feel a little panic building in you. "No. Really! It's okay. I appreciate your help, but I have to be on my way."

The woman will not let go of you. Her expression hardens. "Why? Where are you going?"

You don't know where you are going. You just know you have to get away from this woman and her policemen. You wrench your arm out of her grasp and run for the door.

"Wait!" she yells and runs after you.
12211111.title: Light in the Window

choices: Take your chances on the river
122111111.content:
You don't look back. She is still calling after you.
She stops chasing you when you run past the fence. Instead she turns back around to head inside. To call the police, no doubt.
You don't stop running until you get back to the bridge.
You still have this un easy feeling inside of you. It's not safe here for you, but it's too dark to really see anything. It might be dangerous to travel.
You hear distant voices and it makes you jump. I've got to get out of here, you think to yourself.
You hear a wagon coming close to the bridge. The driver spots you.
"What are you doing out here?" he asks.
"I'm lost and I want to get out of here."
The driver turns around at the sound of the voices. Then he turns back to you. "If you'd like, I can take you to the next village. It is about 5 miles down the road."
You have to think about this for a moment, get in the wagon with a complete stranger or get back in Kayak and take your chances on the river.
"So are you coming or not?"
122111111.title: Risky Travel

1221111111.content:
You hesitate for a few more moments, but then you clamber onto the back of the wagon. The wagon has a sweet smell, like fruit.
"Keep your head down, I'll tell you when you can come up here with me."
You stay down amongst the cargo. You like the smell. You were salavating, and you were so hungry.
"Hey mister," you whisper, "what is this stuff?"
"Picene fruit. Strong stuff. Once you start eating it, it's hard to stop. Better leave it alone. Come up front with me, I have some stuff you can eat."
You climb up front with the driver with your mind still on the fruit.
He hands you some dried meat, you thank him and eat it slowly.
"You got a name kid?"
You think for a moment. You can't remember your name. Should you make one up? Luckily, you are still chewing so you don't have to answer right away.
"I'm Chrack. What brings you to Nevermore? You're not really like anything I've seen before. Most people you resemble you have a third eye. But you don't seem to have one."
You ponder whether to tell him what has happened to you so far. But then you decide against it. You were nervous enough.
Change the subject.
"How far until we get to the next village?"
"Oh probably about 10 minutes or so. Relax kid."
You try to. Your mind goes back to the Picene fruit. You're still hungry.
The time goes by quickly, you see the soft lights of the village.
Chrack pulls in front of an inn.
"You'll like this place. Stay here, I'll ask if they have room."
Chrack leaves you in the wagon and goes outside.
You try to keep control of yourself, but you can't stand it any more, you jump in the back and grab some Picene fruit. You stash it in your pants and climb back into the front of the wagon.
Chrack somes back out. He tosses you a floppy, ragged hat.
"Put this on, no one will stare at you. Come on, we've got a room."
"Why are you being so nice?"
"I was always taught that there was worse people off then you were. You looked like you were in a pretty bad place. Besides, you can help me make that delievery I've gotta do tomorrow morning."
You follow Chrack inside the in. There are all sorts of funny looking people inside. Short, fat leathery blokes with flat ears. Thin pink ladies with funny hats. None of them seemed to notice you. Good thing because you looked REALLY out of place with Chrack. Chrack had lizard skin. He had two eyesockets with two eyes in each one. You were human, there didn't seem to be any of those where you were at.
"Get some sleep kid. Room 22."
He tosses you a key. Then you start up the stairs.
"Sweet dreams kid."
1221111111.title: Village Path

1222.content:
It's very dark in the canyon at night. Directly overhead you can see some stars, but the walls of the canyon are lost in darkness.

Kayak floats along with the current and the gentle rocking makes you sleepy. You lie down in the boat and let the current carry you along. You fall asleep and dream.
1222.title: Night on the River

12221.content:
You dream of a forest at night. In a clearing is a bonfire. The flames leap high, crackling and popping. A circle of naked girls and boys hold hands in a ring around the fire. They alternate girl, boy, girl, boy.

They are singing as they dance around the fire. It sounds very militaristic to your ear, like a Russian marching song. The boys and girls stamp their feet as they circle the fire.

Suddenly you are part of the ring, dancing with them. Up close they are all beautiful, bright eyes flashing and white teeth laughing. A girl holds your right hand and a boy holds your left hand. They both have warm hands that grip your hands tightly.

You hold on tight as the dance speeds up and the circle moves faster and faster. The orange flames of the bonfire illuminate the dancers. Their shadows dance behind them in the forest. Everyone is singing but you don't know the words. You sing along with them as best as you can, trying to make sounds that fit with the song.

The flames leap and twist, reaching high into the darkness and streaming sparks into the sky.

The circle of dancers slows down and stops. You feel your heart beating. This dance is intense. Now everyone raises their arms, still holding hands, and one boy, who is especially tall, gives a loud yell. Down come the hands and you all race for the fire.

Before you can think to refuse, you are jumping into the fire with them.

You expect to be burned, but you are not. It's hot, but a heat like you need when you come in from the cold, warm and toasty. You dance in the flames with everyone else. A girl floats up with fire in her eyes. You see her rise into the sky, her skin glowing like the coals of a fire, bright orange and gold. Her hair is now flame, then her arms and her legs. She becomes part of the fire, an indistinguishable flame.

Another girl rises, a boy, then a girl. It's like popcorn popping - first a few, then all go. Your turn comes quickly and you feel a deep joy. The heat swells inside you and you become pure energy, burning with pleasure that grows more intense as you lose self-awareness and become...
12221.title: Bonfire Dance

122211.content:
The sun wakes you up. During the night Kayak has run into the bank, trapped in some tall river weeds. You sit up in the boat and look around.

Kayak has drifted out of the canyon into a flat plain. The river is wide and sluggish here with water weeds along both banks, tall rushes that are filled with the sounds of insects and birds.

The water is shallow. You take off your shorts and shirt and bathe in the river. It takes the stiffness out of your back and you feel awake and fresh. You realize how hungry you are when the smell of cooking meat wafts by your nose and makes your stomach growl.

You follow your nose through the weeds up onto the bank where two odd characters are cooking on a campfire. They have what might be a rabbit on a stick propped up by a small fire. They are both male, one a boy, one a man. Their clothes are ragged and dirty, but you are surprised to see that they resemble your own clothes, a sleeveless shirt and a pair of shorts, straw-colored.

The older one has a weed stem in his mouth that he chews on. "Did you enjoy your swim?" he asks, and chuckles in the boy's direction.

The boy has a shock of red hair and green eyes. "You're pretty," he says. Your face turns a bit red thinking about these two watching your bath in the river.

The man laughs. "She just got here. When did you leave the node, girl?"

You don't know how to answer. Node? What node?

The man spits out the weed. "The room with the three doors... when did you leave it?"

"Yesterday," you say.

The man winks at the boy "She IS a fresh one!"

Something about his manner makes you nervous, but they are the only humans you have seen and they are wearing clothes like you. They MUST know SOMETHING. "What is this place?" you say.

The man laughs. "You're on Nevermore, darlin'... Planet Number 337 in the League of the True Planets."
122211.title: Second Day

1222111.content:
"You must be hungry," the man says. "How about some rabbit?" He licks his lips. "Mmmmm... good!"

He takes the roasted rabbit off the fire and tears off two of its legs for you and two legs for the boy. He sinks his teeth into what's left and chews loudly. "Mmmm... delicious!"

He is a great admirer of his own cooking, you think, but you are so hungry that the rabbit does indeed taste very delicious. It isn't long before the rabbit is reduced to bones. The man rubs his belly. "We need another one of those, right Tolly?"

The boy grins, "Yeah!"

"Your name is Tolly?" you ask the boy.

"Yeah, I'm Tolly. What's your name?"

"Kayak," you say, unwilling to admit you don't know your own name.

"And my name is Ramp." The man looks at you and you feel nervous again. You feel small and vulnerable, like a rabbit. But you want to know more about this place, so you ask questions and get answers. Or at least as good an answer as Ramp can give you, because it turns out that both of these guys went through what you did.

They found themselves in the room with three doors and then eventually found there way here. Ramp went out the blue door and followed the ledge while Tolly just walked along the river and met Ramp.

Tolly has only been here a few days, but Ramp has been here several months and knows many things. You talk with him as the morning passes and you learn many things.
1222111.title: Ramp and Tolly

12222.content:
The night is dark. The sound of the river is comforting. Falling asleep is easy...

You are on a ship on an ocean of red mud. The mud bubbles and gurgles. The ship is gigantic with multiple decks. The passengers are goblins without any necks. Their heads sit squat on their fat little bodies. And every so often they squat and make potties. The smell is horrendous. You gag and you choke. Why are they laughing? You don't get the joke. They point at your legs and you look down and scream. Your legs are dripping with melted ice cream. It squirts from your navel and makes quite a mess. The goblins just laugh to see your distess. You run to the edge and jump off...

You land in the mud with a *plop* and start sinking. Why did you jump? What were you thinking? That awful ice cream... it's already hazy. Why would ice cream make anyone crazy?

You see the ship pull away in the distance. It gives a long blast on its foghorn. You hear the cackling laughter of the goblins fade away. Now the only sound is the bubbling mud... and you are sinking... slowly... down...
12222.title: Ice Cream

122221.content:
You wake up from your nightmare and your pants are all wet! Something is very wrong.

There is water in the boat. Kayak is sinking! You look around in the darkness. The stars twinkle up above and the reflections of moonlight twinkle in the river, but the riverbanks are just shapeless masses of dark shadows.

You hope the river is not very deep, because soon you will be swimming in it.
122221.title: Wet Pants

1222211.content: You climb out and swim to to the sand bar. Just as you are climbing up the sand dunes, hundreds of naked men and women take you away. They take you to there little camp where they ask you if you like men or women.
1222211.title: Tribal People

123.content:
Out the green door you go, skipping and singing (tra-la-la-la-la-la-laaaa) into a sunny paradise just ripe for adventure. Green leaves everywhere - some big and wide, some long and skinny, some tiny and round - a veritable jungle of excessive foliage.

A pockmarked face looms out of the bushes. "What the hail are you doing heah?" Attached to the face is a scrawny, but strong-looking, man in bib overalls.

You jump back in surprise, accidently letting go of the green door's handle, and it slams shut, trapping you outside with this maniac.

"Nothing!" you say, "I mean... nuttin'!"

"Don't you try to talk my talk, slaw boy!"

"My name ain't Slaw Boy!"

"Well, whut the hail is yo name?"

"My name is Izzy Slak and I'll ask ya right back - Whut's yo name?"

"I see yo game, Slaw Boy, and I ain't playin'"

"I told you my name ain't Slaw Boy! My name is Izzy Slak!"

"Aw, shut yo trap, Slaw Boy! Or do I have to shut it for you?"

You aren't scared, though you are afraid that maybe you should be. You don't shut your trap. "You still ain't told me YOUR name..."

"Yo trap ain't shut, Slaw Boy, but I'll concede that I neglected to answer yo question about my appellation."

"Say, how come you know such a big word like 'appellation'? I coulda sworn you was some kind of ignorant hick."

"I AM an ignorant hick, Slaw Boy! And don't you forget it! I knows the word 'appellation' because I was born in the Appellation Mountains. You ever hear of them?"

"Sho nuff, mountain man. So you is a real hillbilly?"

"They call me the Barnacle Man. You can call me Pete, or Mister B. I don't care which. It don't make no difference."

You realize the old coot is not so crazy after all, just a little eccentric. "Okay, Pete. Say, you got any chow? I'm right hungry."
123.title: The Barnacle Man

1231.content:
"Of course I gots chow, Slaw Boy. Do ya think I roam all over the world without eatin'? You think I am Billy Appleseed, eatin' apples and singin' 'God Bless America' all day, while Babe, my Big Blue Ox, digs up potatoes for me to eat? If you think all that, kid, then you is a little touched in the head."

"No, Mister B,I don't think nothing like that. I'm just hungry, that's all."

"Okay, kid. Sorry. I gets a little excitable sometimes. It's that mountain blood. Now let's eat, shall we?"

"We shall, but where's the food?"

"Patience, little clodhopper. Everthing will be revealed."

"Well then, reveal it, goldang it! I told you I was hungry. Do you wants me to bite your finger off?"

"You is indeed mighty hungry, Slaw Boy. I reckon I better rustle up some grub real fast for ya. Here... Try this."

"What the hail is that!?"

"It's a grub."

"I ain't eaten no earthworm."

"It ain't no earthworm. That there is the larva of a beetle. Go on. You can eat it. I already ate."

"I ain't eatin' bugs, Barnacle Man! Are you crazy?"

Suddenly the Barnacle Man reaches out with his left hand and grabs the neck of your shirt. In Barnacle Man's right hand is the shining blade of a very long knife. His eyes gleam. His face is inches from yours. He whispers slowly, "Don't you ever call me that again, Slaw Boy."

You gulp and manage to squeeze out, "N-No sir, I won't..."

Tension hangs heavy in the air as Barnacle Man tries to milk every last drop of drama from the scene. Will he stick that long shiny knife into your belly or not? At the present moment, you just don't know. Fear grips your heart and squeezes at your insides. You hope fear doesn't squeeze your bladder too hard.

You look into Barnacle Man's blazing eyes. You were so wrong about that "only eccentric" thing. This guy is a full-blown raving lunatic. You feel the cold fingers of fear make contact with your bladder.
1231.title: Chow

choices: You tell her about the green door
124.content:
As you are standing there trying to force your blank mind to make some kind of choice, a woman appears standing on your left. Startled, you jump a bit, but she puts a calming hand on your shoulder and whispers, "Be still, I mean no harm."

Her words calm your pounding heart, allowing you to pause and look at her more closely. She is nearly the same height as you are and her skin is a dark mahogany; the exact color of finely made wood furniture a century old. Her hair is long, trailing down her back in soft tresses that shimmer in the morning breeze. With a shock, you realize it is not "hair" at all. From the widow's peak on her forehead to where the longest strands hide her hips, are extremely fine tree branches like those on a Willow, each adorned with hundreds upon hundreds of downy-soft leaves. The elegant deep green dress she wears is woven from those same leafy branches. Her shoulders are bare, her waist narrow, her breasts full, and she wears neither shoes nor any kind of jewelry.

"Who are you?"

"I am Waonahele of the Willows." She gestures to the many willow trees lining the river bank. "This is my place. How did you come to be here?"
124.title: The Dryad

13.content:
You open the red door. A blast of heat hits you in the face. You are surprised, but step halfway through the door and look around.

It opens into a cavern and there is a river of lava flowing through the cavern. The air is hot, but not unbearable. It reminds you of taking a sauna and you are surprised that the word "sauna" has popped into your mind. Maybe you are getting your memory back.

You step further into the cave and the door slips out of your hand and slams shut! There is no handle or doorknob. You cannot open it to return to the room.

It is dark in the cave, but the lava glows with a red light that provides a dim illumination.

Not far from you is a huge statue carved of stone. You move closer to inspect it and a shudder passes through you. It is a grotesque monster with evil eyes and a mouthful of teeth. In its arms it holds the limp body of a naked boy. With shaking knees you inch closer to the statue until you can verify that the boy, like the monster, is made of stone.

Sounds come from the river of lava - the gurgling and bubbling of it's liquid flow, random pops and hisses, the sound of rock sliding over rock. But on top of these sounds are other sounds that set your teeth on edge - distant screams of pain, hysterical screaming, the screams of someone out of their mind with agony.

The river of lava seems to extend for a long way in both directions. The screams are coming from upstream.
13.title: The Red  Door

131.content:
You walk along beside the river of lava in the direction of its flow. It creeps along so sluggishly that you can easily outpace it. You wonder where it's headed. Maybe it flows out of a crack in the side of a mountain.

It has a timeless quality about it, as though it has been flowing forever, but surely that isn't possible. The lava would have to cool and turn to solid rock.

A squeaking noise overhead is followed by the quick pain of something scratching your face. There are fluttering wings that you beat away with your hands. Bats! The memory of dark creatures of the night flows back into your mind and you become alarmed. Blood-sucking bats! You can hear the flutters and squeaks above your head. They must roost in this part of the caverns.

But now that you are alert, there are no more attacks. Can they sense that you are ready for them? You keep walking.

You don't know how much time has passed. Hours? You are tired and thirsty and hungry. You realize that you could die down here in these caves. A deep sadness fills your heart. It seems unfair that you should die without knowing who you are or why you are here.

The phrase "Life is unfair" crosses your mind and you recognize it as something you heard in that other world, that other place where you existed before waking up in the room with three doors.

You wish that you had chosen a different door than the red one. Surely anything would be better than this underground hell. Hell! Another memory from the world before this one. Demons and the Devil. Your heart sinks. Now you wish you were back in that state of ignorance that you had when you first awakened. You don't want to know these things and feel these fears.
131.title: Downstream

1311.content:
You lose all sense of time as you plod along beside the lava, one foot after the other, like a mechanical man. A mechanical man whose batteries are running down. You notice that you are no longer moving faster than the flow of lava.

Your mouth is dry. You are so thirsty. Perhaps you should rest. Just lie down here on the warm rocks and rest.

You lie down on the warm rocks. Your eyes close. Sleep comes quickly. A deep sleep. You dream. a pleasant dream at first, but then an intruder appears in your dream. A thing like a man, but not a man. A thing with horns and red skin, a thing that laughs at your fear.

You are paralyzed, unable to wake up. You struggle to open your eyes, to move a hand, anything. The thing like a man is big and strong. Muscles ripple in it's arms and legs. It picks you up in its arms and tosses you up and catches you. It laughs. You are screaming in your mind although your mouth makes no sound. It's a long wailing scream that continues even as the thing like a man tosses you out into the river of lava and you feel the hot touch of molten rock on your skin, hear the sizzle of burnt flesh, feel the searing pain...
1311.title: You keep walking

132.content:
You walk toward the screaming. It sends a chill through you, in spite of the great heat in the cavern.

You are feeling kind of dizzy. Your head is spinning, but you stumble on in the red-lit gloom of the cavern of the lava river. You aren't thinking straight. Was it something you ate? Not likely, since there is nothing you've eaten. It's a psycho-attack, like a monkey on your back. Your thoughts are all jumbled. You hear yourself mumbling. There is a weird disassociation between your mind and your brain. Your mind floats ahead. Is this like being dead? You scream and then fall on the ground. Everything's quiet. There is only the sound of the lava, bubbling and gurgling, as it flows through the cavern.

Your mind has come loose from your body. Look! There is your body lying on the ground, but here is your viewpoint running around. It's almost like dreaming, except for the screaming. The screaming, please make it stop!

Everything stops. The lava is frozen. You can see every detail of each bubble and lump. The body on the floor is screaming no more.

Now what to do with this free-floating mental viewpoint that can stop time? You drift over to the rock wall of the cavern and enter it. At first it's quite frightening to be inside of the rock, but then you get used to it and slip through basalt and granite and limestone and marble and suddenly pop out in a room carved in stone where a gigantic throne made of silver and gold stands waiting for a king. It looks very old, but is perfectly clean, and glitters and gleams with a bright metal sheen.
132.title: Upstream

1321.content:
You sit on the throne. Well, not YOU, since it's your viewpoint, your soul, that is flying around. But it FEELS like it's you on the throne since you see what you would see if you really were there.

You clap your hands smartly and four servants run in. Two boys and two girls, all covered in pearls, and everything else is just skin. The pearls catch the light, many sparks of delight, as the four servants bow down before you.

"Bring me my body!" you say in a voice so big and commanding that only a king could possess it.

The servants run out, and you miss them immediately, but there is nothing to do but wait their return. Which doesn't take long, and who comes along, but the body you left on the floor.

They prop it up on the throne, then they leave you alone, and carefully you crawl back inside of your hide.
1321.title: Throne

13211.content:
You sit straight and tall, the ruler of all
Then give your commands to all the great hall

Bring me my servants, my fools and my knaves
Break out the torches and light up these caves

We must have a party, a feast and a fest
Invite all the demons and give them a test

They must find two sinners, two fat evil souls
That then will be roasted over the coals

Over the fire they will twist and will turn
Be careful, you demons, and don't let them burn

And when they are done to a bright golden tan
We'll have a fine evening feasting on man.


These words flow from your mouth without your control, so you understand that you are a puppet king. An evil power controls you now. You try to get up from the throne but you cannot rise. You are the king now and will rule forever. Long live the king!

You begin screaming, a hysterical wail that you have heard before. It sounds like the screaming you heard when you came through the red door. Long live the king.

For ever more ...
13211.title: Long Live the King!

1322.content:
The throne room smells of demons, so you slip back inside the rock and continue on. It's getting warmer and you hear a dull roar. Aha! You must be near the source of the river of lava.

You burst out of the rock into a seething cauldron of liquid lava. The heat is intense and there is the stench of sulfur. The side of one wall breaks off in a rockslide. When the rocks tumble into the hot bubbling lava they explode into showers of rock fragments.

Across the cauldron on a ledge you see a few of the local demons. They look like short naked people with snouts and tails. Their skin is bright red and smooth as rubber and glistens with highlights from the flames that flicker from every crevice in the rocks. Are the demons dancing or just jumping up and down? Above the bubbling roar of the lava you hear their weird demonic laughter bounce off the sides of the cauldron and echo through the cavern.

Fascinating, but you zip back into the solid rock and continue on your way. The freedom of being unattached to your body is exhilirating. Why not fly out into space and explore? Up, up through the rock until finally you are out in the night air, flying toward the moon. Your speed must be trememndous. The moon swells rapidly before you. Within minutes you hit the moon and penetrate it, bursting out the other side. Whoa! You have to slow down if you want to see anything. You circle back and land gently on the moon. It doesn't take long to see that there is nothing there but cold rock.

Bam! You are off and flying, this time aimed at the sun. It's a longer trip than the moontrip was, and you get a little bored. There is nothing to do out here in space but look at the stars. You play connect-the-dots with the stars and a figure begins to take shape. A human being. You trace the shape with your finger, star to star. It's dumb, but it helps keep the long trip to the sun from being so boring. You are beginning to wonder why you even want to go to the sun anyway. Isn't it just a ball of hot gas?

You look at your connect-the-dots figure in the stars again. Does it have a face now? Did it wink at you?
1322.title: Space

133.content:
There is something gleaming on the ground. What did you find?

It looks like something very high-tech. Beyond high-tech, really. It looks positively extraterrestrial. It has that sleek efficient look with an air of mystery about it. It is a deep translucent green with a highly polished sheen.

No controls? Does it read your mind? Or do you have to squeeze it a certain way? Maybe you should know what it does before you try to operate it?

I guess not. You do something that makes it start humming. It's probably too late to throw it down. FLASH! That was bright. You can hardly see. But it's obvious that you are no longer underground. You see stars all around you and over there is the big green and brown ball of a planet.

Hands grab your arms and you struggle. Two men in black uniforms hold you securely.

Now you see that the stars do not completely surround you. You are in a transparent dome. But the base of the dome has an exit. The guards push you into it and you are sucked down through a transparent tube and squirt out into a room with white walls. Luckily the floor is soft and spongey.

You stand up to face a woman with a blaster in her hand aimed at your heart. She is wearing a tight red dress with a flaring collar of gold. A man in a silver jumpsuit walks in.

"Another one?" he asks.

"I'll kill it," the woman says, pointing the blaster at you.

The man pushes her arm down. "No! Haven't you caused enough trouble, already?"

A second man walks in. His jumpsuit is white with a blue emblem on the chest. "They're still spawning? I don't see how they get past security. What node produced this one?"

The man turns toward you. "Where do you come from?"

"I was in a room and opened a red door."

The man nods. "Delta node," he says.

"Destroy it!" the woman whispers.
133.title: Transmatter

1331.content:
The man in silver is disgusted. He shouts at the woman. "That's your only solution, isn't it? Kill this. Destroy that. Don't you realize that we would only be dealing with one node now instead of four if you had just restrained your murderous impulses?"

The woman is furious. "I had to do something! They were spawning. What else could I do but destroy the node? How could I know that two new nodes would arise to replace it?"

"But you destroyed those two as well..."

"They were still spawning! What help were you? There was no input from you. Now you criticise me."

"You could have contacted Galactic Command for help."

"And wait three days for a subspace comm to go through? They were spawning every 8 hours. I had to take action."

"But I don't see what harm they've done. They have no weapons. They don't know anything. Their minds are blank except for a basic knowledge of reality. Why do you fear them so?"

The woman looks up at him, her eyes dark and hostile. "They are an unknown factor. They bypass all our security. Are you a fool that you have no problem with that?"

The man in white speaks up. "How many of them are there now?"

"We aren't even sure about that," says the man in silver. "We know there is one living in Tal Bryn's village in Nevermore Canyon. We found two inactive ones near there by the river. Apparently they fell off the ledge and were damaged when they hit the ground. There have been several sightings on the river. Sometimes they are walking, sometimes in a boat. I don't know how many more."

"It's puzzling," says the man in white. "Continue the investigation. I will give you whatever help you need."

The woman whirls around. "We should blow this planet to smithereens!"

"Calm yourself! This situation has unraveled you. If it were not for your connections, I would have you terminated."

The woman's face goes white. "You dare to threaten me?"

The man in white looks worried. "Of course not! Your help in this is invaluable."

The woman smiles a satisfied smile.

"What about him?" says the man in silver.

"Preserve him," says the man in white.
1331.title: Transmatter (2)

13311.content:
The guards in black drag you over to a padded table fitted with clamps. A memory flashes through your mind of being strapped to a table just like that. It's not a good memory and features lots of screaming.

With a burst of strength, you break out of the guards' grip and take off running.

"Don't kill him!" yells the man in white. You are already running down the hallway with the pounding feet of the guards right behind you.
